The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Noise
Learned about things I would have never associated with noise. Have more questions than answers which I think is a good thing
We learned about what different scholars wrote about noise, from noise in the context of information theory to the differences (if there are any) between noise and music.
I gained a whole new appreciation for the breadth and depth of what could be considered noise.

When I enrolled in the class, I didn't know that noise was a player in so many domains. It is fascinating to think about how deeply it permeates our everyday lives, and all the different ways in which it can be interpreted, captured, and utilized.
Who is defining noise, how, and why?

This course was completely outside of any other experience Ive had at Yale, and I have to say it was the best learning experience of my life. Even more than the awesome time we had, this class gave me a newfound sense of pride in my own creative abilities. Professor Kane truly knows how to foster a fun and meaningful classroom environment that helps everyone no matter their major or experience.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Openendedness of the discussions and projects was great. Fantastic, eclectic group of undergrads and grad students.

The content of the class is enough of a strength; when else do you get the opportunity to just talk about noise for almost two hours every week? But what made it even more intriguing of a class was the people there. The professor does a great job of providing space for students to discuss the readings for the week, and I never feel bored by the endless jokes, projects, insightful messages, and other things we got to share with each other. I can't really think of any weaknesses, but I do wish we could have incorporated more multimedia content (Youtube songs, performances, images) along with the readings or even the lectures.
The course itself was great! I just wish that we could have done more activities in person, especially the creative projects.

The open-ended nature of the course allowed for a lot of individual exploration of topics of interest, which allowed us to flourish creatively. I would have appreciated some more detailed feedback on assignments throughout the course, but discussions were always engaging and fun to be a part of.

This course was so well designed it should be available to everyone as a model for what a well done class looks like. The reading was always interesting, the perspectives were always varied, and the experience as a whole was very clearly crafted around helping the students grow intellectually. When comparing this class to some of the other classes at Yale, I almost feel robbed of a more meaningful college experience. If you want Yale to continue to be a transformative experience, please take this mans advice!!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Zooms were long, but more a function of the platform vs the course schedule.

Being on Zoom allowed some people to share their projects or other things in ways that were accessible to everyone. One project we did was cracked media, and a lot of us ended up sharing videos, which may not have worked out the same way if we met as a class in person. However, Zoom also left room for a lot of awkward silences, and made it overall difficult to always participate and be present.
Our seminar cohort was not huge, so I'm not sure why it wasn't possible to do at least some activities in person, distanced, and masked. That would have improved my experience a lot!
Zoom makes everything tough, but we managed well!
A combo of in class discussion and individual readings/projects was a sturdy framework

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes.
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone looking for a quality writing credit.

I would definitely recommend this class. If you're looking for a class that's different from what you're used to and makes you think about things you usually wouldn't, this is the class for you. Even though it's listed under the Music department, anyone can enjoy this class, from graphic art students in graduate programs to STEM students in undergraduate programs.
Definitely! Professor Kane is one of my favorite teachers, and this course has a great balance between academic/reading tasks and creative projects that would suit a wide variety of students.
Yes! Definitely a great class to engage with such a versatile topic and to explore the nature of noise and sound in a creative way.
Absolutely recommended

Please take this course, and when you do please engage with your peers and with prof Kane. If you put in kindness and respect you will hands down be satisfied with this class and what it gives you in life!
